beginner.vocab: how long? to what point? how far?
beginner.notes: Used to ask 'how long' or 'to what extent' - introduces a question

intermediate.syntax: interrogative adverb limiting 'usque', forms compound expression 'quo usque'
intermediate.style: Part of emphatic opening question for rhetorical effect

advanced.rhetoric: Opens the famous invective with temporal/spatial questioning, building emotional intensity
advanced.etymology: Originally ablative singular neuter of interrogative pronoun quis, used adverbially

beginner.vocab: all the way, right on, as far as, continuously
beginner.grammar: adverb of extent in time or place
beginner.notes: Modifies 'quo' to mean 'how long' or 'up to what point'

intermediate.syntax: Forms compound interrogative 'quo usque' with quo, sometimes written as single word 'quousque'

advanced.rhetoric: Strengthens the opening interrogation, part of the climactic buildup
advanced.usage: Can govern accusative as preposition meaning 'as far as, up to'

beginner.notes: Emphasizes the question - 'how long AT LAST will you...?'

intermediate.syntax: Strengthens 'quo usque' and emphasizes the whole question for rhetorical effect
intermediate.style: Often stands in close conjunction with other adverbs for emphasis

advanced.rhetoric: Corresponds to Greek particle δή for emphasis, creates emotional urgency and exasperation
advanced.literary: Common in invectives and emotional appeals, sometimes found with imperatives

beginner.vocab: you will abuse, misuse, take advantage of
beginner.grammar: 2nd person singular future indicative deponent verb
beginner.notes: Deponent verb - passive form but active meaning. Takes ablative object.

intermediate.syntax: Future tense (not present abuteris) - parallel with following futures eludet, iactabit
intermediate.style: Cicero prefers -re ending over -ris in future indicative passive/deponent

advanced.rhetoric: Future tense suggests ongoing, persistent abuse - not just present moment
advanced.grammar: One of few verbs requiring ablative object (fungor, fruor, utor, abutor, vescor, potior)

beginner.grammar: vocative case - used for direct address
beginner.notes: The person being spoken to directly - 'O Catiline!'

intermediate.syntax: Vocative case of direct address, creating personal confrontation
intermediate.style: Strategic placement after the verb for dramatic effect

advanced.rhetoric: Direct apostrophe to the enemy, making the attack personal and immediate
advanced.historical: Lucius Sergius Catilina, Roman senator who led conspiracy against the state in 63 BCE

beginner.grammar: ablative case - direct object of the deponent verb abutere

intermediate.syntax: Ablative object of abutor - one of the verbs requiring ablative instead of accusative
intermediate.style: Delayed until end of clause for emphasis

advanced.rhetoric: Personifies Roman restraint as something being violated and exploited
advanced.etymology: From patiens (present participle of patior 'to suffer, endure')

beginner.notes: Shows it's 'our patience' - the Roman people's patience

intermediate.syntax: Possessive adjective in agreement with patientia (ablative singular feminine)
intermediate.style: Emphasizes collective Roman identity against individual threat

advanced.rhetoric: Creates us-versus-him dynamic, appeals to collective Roman values and solidarity
advanced.political: Implies Cicero speaks for all Romans, establishing his authority as defender of state
